title: Harold Pinter - Nobel Prize in Literature, 2005 (9 books)
description:
HAROLD PINTER (1930-2008) was an influential English playwright, screenwriter, director and actor whose writing career spanned more than 50 years.  He received dozens of international awards and honors, including the 2005 Nobel Prize in Literature for plays that "uncover the precipice under everyday prattle and force entry into oppression's closed rooms."

His best-known plays include "The Birthday Party" (1957), "The Homecoming" (1964), and "Betrayal" (1978), each of which he adapted for the screen.  His screenplay adaptations of others' works include "The Servant" (1963), "The Go-Between" (1971), "The French Lieutenant's Woman" (1981), "The Trial" (1993), and "Sleuth" (2007).  He also directed or acted in radio, stage, television, and film productions of his own and others' works.

In addition to plays and screenplays, this collection includes a selection of his poetry and prose, a series of conversations conducted with Mel Gussow, and his Nobel Lecture.


The following books are in ePUB/MOBI format unless otherwise indicated:

* ART, TRUTH & POLITICS: The Nobel Lecture (Route, 2006). -- PDF

* CONVERSATIONS WITH PINTER [by Mel Gussow] (Limelight Editions, 1994).

* FIVE SCREENPLAYS: The Servant / The Pumpkin Eater / The Quiller Memorandum / Accident / The Go-Between (Grove, 1973). -- PDF

* TWO PLAYS AND A FILM SCRIPT: The Lover / Tea Party / The Basement (Grove, 1967). -- PDF

* PLAYS 1 (Faber & Faber, 1991).
Includes "The Birthday Party", "The Room", "The Dumb Waiter", "A Slight Ache", "The Hothouse", "A Night Out", "The Black and White", and "The Examination".

* PLAYS 2 (Faber & Faber, 1991).
Includes "The Caretaker", "The Lover", and several other shorter pieces from the same period: "The Dwarfs", "Night School", "Trouble in the Works", "The Black and White", "Request Stop", "Last to Go", and "Special Offer".

* PLAYS 3 (Faber & Faber, 1991).
Includes "The Homecoming", "Old Times", "No Man's Land", four shorter plays, six revue sketches, a short story, and the speech given in 1970 on being awarded the German Shakespeare Prize.

* PLAYS 4 (Faber & Faber, 1993).
Includes "Betrayal", "Monologue", "One for the Road", "Mountain Language", "Family Voices", "A Kind of Alaska", "Victoria Station", "Precisely", "The New World Order", "Party Time", "Moonlight", "Ashes to Ashes" and "Celebration".

* VARIOUS VOICES: Sixty Years of Prose, Poetry, Politics, 1948-2008 (Faber & Faber, 2009).
